intro: Mentha retinervis, commonly known as the veined mint, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to southern Europe and parts of North Africa. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant has opposite, ovate to lanceolate leaves with prominent veins, giving it its common name. Its small, tubular flowers are typically pink or purple and are arranged in whorled clusters. Mentha retinervis is often used in traditional medicine and as a culinary herb due to its aromatic properties.
